notes:
1. Definition

Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) is a systematic analysis of the potential environmental impacts of a product, process, or service throughout its entire life cycle. This is often referred to as a "cradle-to-grave" or "cradle-to-cradle" analysis.

2. Stages of a Life Cycle

An LCA considers environmental impacts at all stages, including:

  1. Raw Material Extraction: Acquiring raw materials from the earth (e.g., mining ore, harvesting timber).
  2. Manufacturing and Processing: Converting raw materials into a finished product.
  3. Transportation and Distribution: Moving materials and products between stages.
  4. Product Use: The operational life of the product, including energy consumption and maintenance.
  5. End-of-Life: Disposal, recycling, or reuse of the product after it is no longer useful.

3. Purpose

The goal of an LCA is to identify and quantify the energy and materials used and the wastes released into the environment. This helps engineers and designers to:

  • Identify opportunities for environmental improvements.
  • Compare different products or design choices.
  • Avoid "burden shifting," where solving one environmental problem creates another one elsewhere in the life cycle.

solvedExamples.question: A Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) of a plastic water bottle would typically include all of the following stages EXCEPT:

options.text: The environmental impact of oil extraction to produce the plastic.
The energy used to manufacture and transport the bottle.
The environmental impact of the product being advertised on television.
The fate of the bottle after it is thrown away (landfill or recycling).

solvedExamples.explanation: LCA focuses on the physical life cycle of a product, from raw material extraction to end-of-life disposal. While advertising has its own resource use, it is generally considered outside the scope of the product's direct environmental impact assessment.
